item.title: Stock Analysis
item.description: In this chapter, we will investigate stock data from NYSE and DIJA. While doing so, basic financial theory and concepts will be explained and applied to real stock data.

item.title: Stock Returns
item.description: We will use the tidyquant package to download historical data of stock prices, calculate returns, and examine the distribution of returns. The file nyse.csv contains 508 stocks listed on the NYSE, their ticker symbol, name, the IPO (Initial Public Offering) year, and the sector and industry the company is in. nyse <- read_csv(here::here("data","nyse.csv")) First, we want to get have a look at the industries the companies are operating in. Therefore, we create bar plot that shows as how many companies are in each industry.

item.title: The Inverted Yield Curve
item.description: The inverted yield curve Every so often, we hear warnings from commentators on the “inverted yield curve” and its predictive power with respect to recessions. An explainer what a inverted yield curve is can be found here. If you’d rather listen to something, here is a great podcast from NPR on yield curve indicators In addition, many articles and commentators think that, e.g., Yield curve inversion is viewed as a harbinger of recession.

item.title: GDP Decomposition
item.description: GDP components over time and among countries At the risk of oversimplifying things, the main components of gross domestic product, GDP are Personal Consumption (C), business investment (I), government spending (G) and net exports. You can read more about GDP and the different approaches in calculating at the Wikipedia GDP page. The GDP data we will look at is from the United Nations’ National Accounts Main Aggregates Database, which contains estimates of total GDP and its components for all countries from 1970 to today.
